
	
	
	



	
	
	


<p style="text-align: left;"><h1><font face="Liberation Serif, serif" style="font-weight: normal;"><font color="#3399ff">Operating
System (P</font><font color="#3399ff">2</font><font color="#3399ff">)</font></font></h1><span style="font-weight: normal;"><br></span><font face="Liberation Serif, serif" style="font-weight: normal;">	Operating
systems are the software that makes you use the computer more easily.
They are the interface between machine and man. The OS manages all
the hardware in the computer telling the processor what to do.
Without an operating system it would be impossible to use a computer,
they'd be useless.<br></font><font face="Liberation Serif, serif" style="font-weight: normal;">	Nowadays it
is not common, but sometime ago there were some different
characteristics in the operating systems. Such as single-user OS
(only has one user in the computer), single-tasking which only runs
one task at a time. There were also the command line operating
system, that consisted in a console form where you had to type
commands manually to use the computer, ex.: to create a folder in an
Ubuntu (Linux) console distribution you would have to type:</font></p><p style="text-align: left;"><span style="font-weight: normal;"><font face="Liberation Serif, serif"><br></font></span><img src="data:image/png;base64," name="Image4" align="left" width="568" height="36" border="0" style="text-align: left;"><span style="font-weight: normal;"><br></span><br><br><font face="Liberation Serif, serif" style="font-weight: normal;">	Today there
are mainly three computer OSs in the market: Windows, MAC OS and
Linux (all of them are based on GUI). Depending on which system you
are using it may give you different functions and different methods
of doing things.  Also according to your OS the drivers which are the
software that tells the computer how to deal with a specific
component (such as GPU or a USB Flash Drive) may be different, and
some may not be available.&nbsp;</font></p>
